Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Behavior of Policymakers: Accountability, Other-Regarding Behavior and Fiduciary Motivation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research that will use formal modeling and empirical methods, including laboratory decision making experiments, to develop and test a number of hypothesis about the factors that determine the behavior of elected group leaders. The overall goal is to consider how the way a leader was selected affects his/her leadership decisions. For elected leaders, concern for one's supporters, the desire for re-election, and a fiduciary interest in the group's overall wellbeing may interact to determine how leaders make decisions. Appointed or promoted leaders would make different decisions. The project advances science by developing and testing richer theories of leadership. The work may give us new practical insights on the best way to choose leaders for groups.

Current theories in political economy view policymakers (whether they are elected or appointed) as economic agents with their own motivations and objectives. However, these leaders generally have a mix of objectives, ranging from ideology to re-election to concern for the public good. The project examines how this mix of objectives affects leadership decisions. The first part of the project considers structural estimation of a political agency model. The second part of the project includes theoretical and empirical investigation of other-regarding? behavior by office holders who are not driven by re-election. The last part of the project uses lab experiments to test the theory that other-regarding behavior by policymakers is in part the result of a fiduciary motive. That is, simply holding an elected office makes individuals more likely to value the common good.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to better understand the behavior of policymakers in order to enhance our understanding of policy choices in representative democracy. The project had three parts: theoretical modeling of behavior of policymakers; laboratory experiments on the behavior of elected and appointed decision makers, and, econometric analysis of elections and the behavior of policymakers.

One key aspect was how politicians react to voter behavior, where I found that candidates reward those who voted for them in past races if they are not in close races, but direct benefits toward potential swing voters in close races. I also considered how voter reaction to candidates affects their policy choices, where it was shown that dislike of candidates on general grounds induces them to adopt more extreme policies in order to motivate their core supporters. Major empirical was conducted to learn the extent to which personal characteristics influence voting in US Presidential elections  

 A second area of research was to sharpen understanding of the extent to which reelection incentives affect the performance of incumbents. Using data from US governors limited to two terms, it was found that the possibility of reelection provides a significant incentive for incumbents to exert effort in their first term, that is, a disciplining effect. I also find a positive but weaker selection effect, that is, the electoral process works to choose governors who perform better once in office.

Another area of research was on campaign contributions, specifically on political fundraising from small donors. The goal was to study how donor characteristics, such as income levels, affect fundraisers’ behavior. Campaign finance regulation to limit the influence of large donors was also considered, with policy recommendations for campaign finance reform.

Since these projects concern leader behavior, both in and between elections, it is conceivable that there may be effects on political discourse and perhaps even on citizen expectations of behavior of political leaders. More generally, it may be potentially useful to decision makers in organizations outside of government. This may lead to greater ability of organizations, both governmental and non-governmental, to achieve their objectives, as well as increased citizen understanding of, and hence support for, the democratic process.
